com.zephyr.internal

Class I2CComm

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.zephyr.internal.I2CComm
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    CommMiddleMan

    public class I2CComm
extends java.lang.Object
implements CommMiddleMan
    This class acts as a bridge between the SerialPort communication profile and the rest of the code. It implements the CommMiddleMan interface to make it so that it can be used in conjunction with the other two communication styles dynamically without having to have code specific to each communication type
    Author:
    Bradley Bickford

    • Method Detail

      • readByte

        public java.lang.Byte readByte()
        Description copied from interface: CommMiddleMan
        Reads a byte from the communication device type. For the most part, the only thing that this is used for is re-synchronizing the the bytes coming from the Pixy should we start pulling data out of order
        Specified by:
        readByte in interface CommMiddleMan
        Returns:
        The byte that was read, returns null if the read fails

      • readShort

        public java.lang.Short readShort()
        Description copied from interface: CommMiddleMan
        Reads a short (2 bytes) from the communication device type. This gets used the most, as the data that comes from the Pixy is all shorts.
        Specified by:
        readShort in interface CommMiddleMan
        Returns:
        The short that was read, returns null if the read fails

      • write

        public void write(byte[] bytes)
        Description copied from interface: CommMiddleMan
        Writes a series of bytes to the communication device type.
        Specified by:
        write in interface CommMiddleMan
        Parameters:
        bytes - The bytes to write

      • write

        public void write(java.nio.ByteBuffer buffer)
        Description copied from interface: CommMiddleMan
        Writes an NIO ByteBuffer object to the communication device type. This is used the most because it makes it easier to break down the bytes in a short a little easier, the only issue being that ByteBuffers do require slightly more memory and processing overhead to work with because they are Objects and not primitive types
        Specified by:
        write in interface CommMiddleMan
        Parameters:
        buffer - The ByteBuffer to write
